item.title: video_fyra
item.description: I have uploaded a long (~1 hour) video to youtube, where I show how to configure and use my layout script i3fyra. www.youtube.com/watch?v=t4Tve-xpwus Below are the things I added to the default i3 config file (~/.config/i3/config). # focus replacements bindsym $mod+Left exec --no-startup-id exec i3fyra -f l bindsym $mod+Down exec --no-startup-id exec i3fyra -f d bindsym $mod+Up exec --no-startup-id exec i3fyra -f u bindsym $mod+Right exec --no-startup-id exec i3fyra -f r # tabswitching bindsym $mod+Tab exec --no-startup-id exec i3fyra -t r bindsym $mod+Shift+Tab exec --no-startup-id exec i3fyra -t l # move replacements bindsym $mod+Shift+Left exec --no-startup-id exec i3fyra -m l bindsym $mod+Shift+Down exec --no-startup-id exec i3fyra -m d bindsym $mod+Shift+Up exec --no-startup-id exec i3fyra -m u bindsym $mod+Shift+Right exec --no-startup-id exec i3fyra -m r # floating toggle replacement bindsym $mod+Shift+space exec --no-startup-id i3fyra -a # window rules for_window [class="^.

item.title: fixed_fixedsys
item.description: I’m not sure why, but Fixedsys is one of my all time favorite fonts. I particularly like it as a monospaced terminal and programming font (Fixedsys is the font used on this site to display code and ASCII art). But it hasn’t been painless to get the terminal to accept Fixedsys. The problem from the start is that the available version of Fixedsys is a .ttf font. After some digging around the Internet, I found this article on askubuntu.

item.title: extreme_i3
item.description: I finally did it! I Uploaded my i3 layout script, i3fyra. I have been working on it for almost a year. I think it works good enough to publish now. item.title: budbar
item.description: Polybar is a great statusbar that works well with i3 and other window managers, this is my config file. item.title: i3fyra
item.description: fyra is the Swedish name for “four”. www.youtube.com/watch?v=kU8gb6WLFk8 . www.youtube.com/watch?v=t4Tve-xpwus In the first video above I show the functionality of i3fyra. The layout consists of four containers: A B C D The internal layout of the containers doesn’t matter.

item.title: i3list
item.description: This script is vital for i3fyra to work. But it can be used on it’s own or with other scripts. i3list is also used by i3run. i3list parses the output of the command: i3-msg -t get_tree and returns a long string with 43 values separated by spaces. This strange output format is made to make it possible to pipe the output to other scripts. A lot of the information is specific to i3fyra, but if i3list doesn’t find a value an X will be placed in it’s place in the output.

item.title: i3term
item.description: I just made this script to keep my i3config cleaner. It probably needs tweaking if someone other then budRich uses it ;) Launch a command in a new urxvt window Uses i3run to run or raise a window with the instancename: COMMAND. If no window is found, COMMAND is ran in a urxvt window with the same instance name as COMMAND. When the command exits window is cleared and returned to bash.

item.title: the_site
item.description: This site is made using the static site generator Hugo and the text editor Sublime Text, using GNU/Linux as an IDE. I wanted a static site because cutting edge web development techniques and bloated IDE’s is not an environment I like. I have promised myself that the rendered site should only be HTML/CSS (except for google analytics and disqus). There is a lot of crazy stuff and bash scripting involved in creating the site, but that doesn’t affect the finished site or your RAM and bandwidth usage.

item.title: fresh_start
item.description: These are the steps I take to setup my work environment on a fresh install of Peppermint OS 8. Most of the steps are valid on other GNU/Linux distributions, but I don’t recommend anyone to blindly follow and install everything. Before doing anything else i start syncing Dropbox. I start with this step because it can take up to 45 minutes, so while Dropbox is syncing there is time to install and setup other programs.

item.title: perfect_folders

It uses Dropbox to ensure cloud based backup and Hugo to create this site you are looking at where many of my actual dotfiles and scripts are viewable and auto-updated. folder structure This might look overcomplicated and hard to setup, but it actually makes a lot of sense and takes no time to setup.

item.title: mouseback
item.description: A while ago I got irritated how messy my i3 config file looked, and I researched alternative hotkey managers. I tried sxhkd and it is a fine piece of code. I got a much cleaner setup of the hotkeys and I could do stuff that i wasn’t able to do with i3. But a couple of days ago, i realized that my i3 config could be just as clean as sxhkd by using variables.

item.title: swedish_keyboards
item.description: when I was working as a technical support agent I received several calls from angry men who couldn’t find the @ symbol on the keyboard. When I explained that they had to hold Alt-Gr and pressing 2 at the same time, they exploded with anger and told me to tell the technicians to make a new keyboard layout! I explained it’s an old standard and agreed it was stupid, but that it would probably never change.

item.title: me_myself_and_i3
item.description: Or, how I became a tiler i3 is a dynamic window manager for X. I use i3, and I really like it. There are many similar window managers and I haven’t tried many of them. I have run and tinkered with bug.n on windows and tested awesome and dwm on GNU/Linux. Maybe I was unlucky and had bad timing with awesome, I was very fresh on GNU/Linux and I think the awesome project was in a transition phase, but I had a hard time grasping all of it.

item.title: install_i3
item.description: You can probably install i3 directly from your distributions package manager. But If you want to be sure to get the latest version or a fork you need to download and compile the source code. i3-gaps i3-gaps is a fork of i3 developed by Airblader who happens to be one of the main developers on vanilla/normal i3. i3-gaps has some features that is not 100% in sync with the design philosophy of normal i3, that’s why it is a fork.

item.title: bashrc
item.description: The read -rsn1 -t2 input waits two seconds for a key-press before it starts X and i3. If I press 1 I stay in the wonderful tty environment. If I press 2 or wait 2 seconds, i3 starts. I have found this method much more convenient then a normal DM, where you have to change DE from some, very easily forgotten, menu. Often resulting in me logging in to the wrong DE…

item.title: xinitrc
item.description: This is part of my anti-DM suite. The stuff I want to happen just before i3 loads up, goes here. Starting urxvt in daemon mode is really nice and makes it consume less resources and spawn new terminal windows much faster. I use hsetroot to set the desktop background to a minimal tiled pattern and use the background color from Xresources. The Seba keyboard layout keeps me sane! I also have some special options to setxkbmap.

item.title: compton
item.description: compton is a lightweight compositor for X that works really well with i3. A compositor adds some eye-candy like transparency and drop-shadows to the windows. But it also do some anti screen tearing magic and such. The compton setup can however be a bit tricky and it all depends on your own preferences and hardware. The blocks below are more i3 then hardware related that you might find useful: opacity-rule = [ # these transparency rules makes windows in tabs/stacks look good.

item.title: preferences
item.description: Klavaro is a GTK touch typing trainer. It is really nice to just sit and listen to a pod while the fingers flow. My average WPM is around 55 at the moment. But I slowly improve. I believe touch typing is very important to master if you want to become a good programmer. If you never have given touch typing a thought, i really recommend you read Programming’s Dirtiest Little Secret by Steve Yegge.

item.title: i3syntax
item.description: This Sublime Text package adds a simple syntax highlighting to the i3 config. It only adds highlighting to comments. Installing the package also adds the ability to toggle comments. You can also define “symbols” (default hotkey in sublime: ctrl+r) by making a comment in this fashion: # > this is a section. I host this package on github.

item.title: igi
item.description: This script generates an issue file that is shown when you log in to your computer without a DM. It applies the current color scheme that you have set in .Xresources ss_igi1.png dependencies toilet display ASCII artish fonts lolcat rainbow color effect on terminal output fortune prints a random fortune The script has a sudo mv command, which requires you to enter a password.

item.title: i3zen
item.description: I made a post on /r/unixporn where you can view an animated gif of i3zen in action. Put the window between two ghosts (centered). if the window already is “zen”, move it back to its original workspace. If the window is not in zen but another window is, both of them will be zen in a tabbed container. usage $ i3zen [OPTION] ARGUMENT option argument function -v show version info and exit -h show this help and exit dependencies i3get i3gw

item.title: i3run
item.description: This is a run or raise or hide script for i3wm. It looks for a window matching a given criteria. These are the actions taken depending on the state of the found window: target window state action Active and not handled by i3fyra mark and hide Active and handled by i3fyra do nothing Handled by i3fyra and hidden show container, activate Not handled by i3fyra and hidden show window, activate Not on current workspace goto workspace Not found run command Hidden in this context, means that window is on scratchpad/ Show in this context means, move window to current workspace.

item.title: i3mtm
item.description: When launched without options, i3mtm checks floating status of current window. If it is tiled, the window becomes floating. If it is floating, a search for marks is done, if no marks are found, window becomes tiled. Otherwise a dmenu asks for a mark to move window to. If no selection is made, window is tiled but not moved. Otherwise window is tiled and moved to selected mark. With -m option window is treaded as if it was floating even if it is tiled.

item.title: i3gw
item.description: In the screenshot below, the windows to the right are tiled, and a ghostwindow is tiled on the left half of the screen. The other windows are floating. ss-i3gw1.png A Ghost window wrapper for i3wm. i3-msg has an undocumented function (open) that creates empty containers, or as I call them: ghosts. Since these empty containers doesn’t contain any windows there is no instance/class/title to identify them, making it difficult to control them.

item.title: i3get
item.description: Search for windows in i3 tree, return desired information if no arguments are passed. con_id of acitve window is returned. usage $ i3get [OPTION [CRITERIA]] option criteria function -v show version and exit -h show this help -a currently active window (default) -c CLASS search for windows with the given class -i INSTANCE search for windows with the given instance -t TITLE search for windows with title.

item.title: i3cast
item.description: Create and upload screen recordings usage $ i3cast [-v|-h] option argument function -v show version info and exit -h show this help and exit Just run the script to start the recording run it again to stop and preview the recording and perform action, (save,upload or play again). if no action is selected the recording is deleted.

item.title: subact
item.description: This is a script I wrote to automate the process of uploading scripts and dotfiles to this web site. It analyzes the title of Sublime Text to get the filename of the currently open file. If the file is in ~/bin (my local scripfolder), it is a scriptfile, else it is a dotfile. Depending on the type it is sent to different directories within my hugo project folder. Which is on my Dropbox.
